description: From Middle English stuffen (“to equip, furnish”), borrowed from Old French estoffer, estofer (“to provide what is necessary, equip, stuff”), borrowed from Old High German stoffōn, from Proto-West Germanic *stoppōn (“to clog up, block, fill”). More at stop.

definitionGroups.group: (informal) Miscellaneous items or objects; (with possessive) personal effects.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, uncountable) Furniture; goods; domestic vessels or utensils.
(informal) Unspecified things or matters.
examples: I had to do some stuff.

definitionGroups.group: The tangible substance that goes into the makeup of a physical object.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A material for making clothing; any woven textile, but especially a woollen fabric.
(archaic) Boards used for building.
Abstract/figurative substance or character.
Paper stock ground ready for use. When partly ground, it is called half stuff.
(informal) Used as placeholder, usually for material of unknown type or name.
examples: Synonyms: doodad, thingamabob; see also Thesaurus:thingy
Can I have some of that stuff on my ice-cream sundae?

entries.meaning: (slang) Narcotic drugs, especially heroin.
examples: Synonyms: dope, gear; see also Thesaurus:recreational drug

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A medicine or mixture; a potion.
(sometimes euphemistic) Refuse or worthless matter; hence, also, foolish or irrational language.
examples: Synonyms: garbage, rubbish, nonsense, stuff and nonsense; see also Thesaurus:trash, Thesaurus:nonsense
Don't give me any of that 'what-about' stuff!

entries.meaning: (nautical) A melted mass of turpentine, tallow, etc., with which the masts, sides, and bottom of a ship are smeared for lubrication.
(slang, criminal argot, dated) Money.

verbs.description: stuff (third-person singular simple present stuffs, present participle stuffing, simple past and past participle stuffed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill by packing or crowding something into; to cram with something; to load to excess.
examples: I'm going to stuff this pillow with feathers.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill a space with (something) in a compressed manner.
examples: He stuffed his clothes into the closet and shut the door.

entries.meaning: (transitive, cooking) To fill with seasoning.
examples: She stuffed the turkey for Thanksgiving using her secret recipe.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To load goods into (a container) for transport.
(transitive, used in the passive) To sate.
examples: I’m stuffed after having eaten all that turkey, mashed potatoes and delicious stuffing.

entries.meaning: (takes a reflexive pronoun) To eat, especially in a hearty or greedy manner.
examples: Synonyms: fill one's face, feed one's face, stuff one's face
She sits on the sofa all day, watching TV and stuffing herself with cream buns.

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, Australia, New Zealand) To break; to destroy.
examples: He skidded off the road and totally stuffed his brand new car.

entries.meaning: (transitive, vulgar, Britain, Australia, New Zealand) To sexually penetrate.
examples: Synonyms: fuck, root, screw
His wife came home early and found him on the couch stuffing the maid.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mildly vulgar, often imperative) Used to contemptuously dismiss or reject something. See also stuff it.
examples: Stuff your stupid rules, I'll do what I like.

entries.meaning: (informal) To heavily defeat or get the better of.
examples: Mudchester Rovers were stuffed 7-0 in the semi-final.
They totally stuffed us in that business deal.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut off another competitor in a race by disturbing his projected and committed racing line (trajectory) by an abrupt manoeuvre.
examples: I got stuffed by that guy on the supermoto going into that turn, almost causing us to crash.

entries.meaning: To preserve a dead bird or other animal by filling its skin.
(transitive) To obstruct, as any of the organs; to affect with some obstruction in the organs of sense or respiration.
(transitive) To form or fashion by packing with the necessary material.
examples: An Eastern king put a judge to death for an iniquitous sentence, and ordered his hide to be stuffed into a cushion, and placed upon the tribunal.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To crowd with facts; to cram the mind of; sometimes, to crowd or fill with false or idle tales or fancies.
(transitive, computing) To compress (a file or files) in the StuffIt format, to be unstuffed later.
